verse.text: Paul and Timothy, [xref]a[/xref]slaves of Christ Jesus, to all the [xref]b[/xref]saints in Christ Jesus who are in [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Philippi, [note]2[/note]with the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]overseers and [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]deacons:
verse.note: Philippi was the chief city in the province of Macedonia of the ancient Roman Empire ([link]Acts 16:12[/link]). Through Paul's first ministry journey to Europe ([link]Acts 16:10-12[/link]), the first church in Europe was raised up in that city.

Here it is not "the saints...[i]and[/i] the overseers and deacons"; rather, it is "the saints...[i]with[/i] the overseers and deacons." This is highly significant in that it indicates that in the local church the saints, the overseers, and the deacons are not three groups. The church has only one group, composed of all the saints (including the overseers and deacons), who are the components of a local church. This indicates further that in any locality there should be just one church with one group of people, comprising all the saints in that locality.

Overseers are the elders in a local church ([link]Acts 20:17[/link], [link]28[/link]). [i]Elder[/i] denotes the person, and [i]overseer[/i] the function. An overseer is an elder in function. Here overseers are mentioned instead of elders, indicating that the elders were fulfilling their responsibility.

The Greek word means [i]serving ones.[/i] The deacons are the serving ones in a local church and are under the direction of the overseers ([link]1 Tim. 3:8[/link]). This verse, showing that a local church is composed of the saints, with overseers to take the lead and deacons to serve, indicates that the church in Philippi was in good order.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Grace to you and [note]2[/note]peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link].

verse.text: I [xref]a[/xref]thank my God upon all my remembrance of you,
Always in my every [xref]a[/xref]petition on behalf of you all, making my [xref]a[/xref]petition with [xref]b[/xref]joy,
For your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fellowship unto [i]the furtherance of[/i] the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]gospel from the first day until now,
verse.note: [i]Fellowship[/i] here means [i]participation, communication.[/i] See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 15[/link]. The saints in Philippi had fellowship unto the gospel, participating in the furtherance of the gospel through the apostle Paul's ministry. This participation included their financial contributions to the apostle ([link]4:10[/link], [link]15-16[/link]), which issued in the furtherance of the gospel. This kind of fellowship, which kept them from being individualistic and diversely minded, implies that they were one with the apostle Paul and with one another. This gave them the ground for their experience and enjoyment of Christ, which is the main point of this book. The Christ-experiencing and -enjoying life is a life in the furtherance of the gospel, a gospel-preaching life, not individualistic but corporate. Hence, there is the fellowship unto the furtherance of the gospel. The more fellowship we have in the furtherance of the gospel, the more Christ we experience and enjoy. This kills our self, ambition, preference, and choice.

Concerning the gospel, in this book Paul used several significant terms: [i]fellowship unto[/i]... the gospel, [i]the defense and confirmation of the gospel[/i] ([link]v. 7[/link]), [i]the advancement of the gospel[/i] ([link]v. 12[/link]), and [i]the faith of the gospel[/i] ([link]v. 27[/link]). Paul's preaching of Christ as the gospel included fellowship, defense, confirmation, advancement, and the faith. In contrast, the Judaistic believers preached Christ out of rivalry, factiousness, selfish ambition, envy, and strife, and did not cause the gospel to advance.

verse.text: Being confident of this very thing, that He who has begun in you a good work will complete it until the [xref]a[/xref]day of Christ Jesus;

Even as it is right for me to think this concerning you all because you have me in your heart, since both in my [xref]a[/xref]bonds and in the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]defense and confirmation of the gospel you are all [note]2[/note]fellow partakers [note]3[/note]with me of grace.
verse.note: On the negative side, the defense of the gospel is for the resisting of perverting and distorting heresies, such as Judaism, dealt with in Galatians, and Gnosticism, dealt with in Colossians. On the positive side, the confirmation of the gospel is for the announcing of the revelations of God's mysteries concerning Christ and the church as unveiled in the apostle's Epistles. In preaching such a gospel according to God's economy, Paul renounced religion, law, culture, ordinances, customs, habits, and every kind of "ism" — everything that was apart from God's economy. Because Paul preached such a gospel, he was regarded as a troublemaker, a pest ([link]Acts 24:5[/link]).

Fellow partakers of grace are those who share and enjoy the processed Triune God as grace. The apostle was such in the defense and confirmation of the gospel, and the saints in Philippi were fellow partakers with him in this grace.

Or, of my grace. Paul's grace was the grace that he enjoyed and that surpassed his sufferings in the defense and confirmation of the gospel. This grace was not God objectively; it was the Triune God processed to be his portion subjectively and experientially.

verse.text: For God is my [xref]a[/xref]witness how I [xref]b[/xref]long after you all in the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]inward parts of Christ Jesus.
verse.note: Lit., bowels; signifying inward affection, then, tender mercy and sympathy. In longing after the saints, the apostle was one with Christ even in the bowels, the tender inward parts, of Christ. This indicates that for Paul to enjoy Christ meant that he was one with Christ's inward parts, in which he enjoyed Christ as the supply of grace.

verse.text: And this I pray, that your [xref]a[/xref]love may abound yet more and more in [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]full knowledge and all [note]2[/note]discernment,
verse.note: The Philippian believers had much love. Yet their love needed to abound, to overflow more and more, not foolishly but in full knowledge, not in ignorance but in all discernment, that they might approve by testing the things that differ and are more excellent. This should include the discerning of the differing preachings of the gospel in [link]vv. 15-18[/link] and of the different kinds of people in [link]3:2-3[/link].

Sensitive perception, moral tact. Paul's desire was that the Philippians, some of whom had been distracted from God's economy by the preaching of the Judaistic believers, would not love the Judaistic believers foolishly but would love them soberly with love that abounded in full knowledge and sensitive perception.

verse.text: So that you may [xref]a[/xref]approve by testing the things which differ and are more excellent, that you may be [note]1[/note]pure and [note]2[/note]without offense unto the [xref]b[/xref]day of Christ,
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]judged by sunlight.[/i] I.e., tested as genuine; hence, pure, sincere.
Or, unoffending; not stumbling others.

verse.text: Being filled with the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fruit of righteousness, which is [xref]b[/xref]through Jesus Christ, to the [xref]c[/xref]glory and praise of God.
verse.note: The fruit of righteousness is the living product of the believers' living a proper life by the element of righteousness, with a righteous standing before God and man. Such a life could be lived not by the believers' natural man for their boast but through Jesus Christ as the believers' life, experienced by them to the glory and praise of God.

verse.text: Now I want you to know, brothers, that the things concerning me have turned out rather to the [note]1[/note]advancement of the [xref]a[/xref]gospel,
verse.note: Advancement made by the pioneers who cut the way before an army to further its march. Paul's sufferings made such an advancement for the gospel.

verse.text: So that my [xref]a[/xref]bonds have become manifest [i]as being[/i] [note]1[/note]in Christ among the whole [note]2[/note]Praetorian guard and to all the rest.
verse.note: I.e., for Christ's sake.
The imperial guard of Caesar.

verse.text: And most of the brothers, being confident in the Lord because of my bonds, are more exceedingly bold to speak the word of God without fear.
[note]1[/note]Some preach Christ even because of [xref]a[/xref]envy and [note]2[/note]strife, and [note]3[/note]some also because of good will,
verse.note: Those Christians who were opposing Paul and his ministry ([link]2 Cor. 10:7[/link]; [link]11:22-23[/link]). Even at the apostle's time there were some who preached the gospel out of envy of Paul and in strife with him.
Factiousness, partisanship.
Those who had fellowship with Paul and participated with him in the preaching of the gospel.

verse.text: These out of love, knowing that I am set for the [xref]a[/xref]defense of the gospel.
But the others announce Christ out of [note]1[/note]selfish ambition, not purely, thinking to raise up [note]2[/note]affliction in my [xref]a[/xref]bonds.
verse.note: Self-seeking, rivalry, faction.

Lit., pressure. Those who announced Christ out of selfish ambition endeavored to make Paul's bonds press him more heavily by depreciating him and his ministry while he was outwardly laid aside from his preaching. Paul's affliction in bonds was due not to his preaching of the gospel but to his defense of the gospel. The Judaizers mixed the gospel with the law and circumcision. Paul defended it. This caused the riot which put him into bonds ([link]Acts 21:27-36[/link]).

verse.text: What then? Only that in every way, whether in pretense or in truthfulness, Christ is announced; and in this I [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rejoice; yes, and I will rejoice;
verse.note: The apostle's heart was so broadened by grace that he even rejoiced in his opposers' preaching of Christ in pretense. What an upright spirit this is! This was the outworking of the life, nature, and mind of Christ, who lived in the apostle. His experience of Christ was an enjoyment. Such a life rejoices no matter what the circumstances may be.

verse.text: For I know that for me this will turn out to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]salvation through [note]2[/note]your [xref]b[/xref]petition and [i]the[/i] [note]3[/note]bountiful [xref]c[/xref]supply of the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]Spirit of Jesus Christ,
verse.note: The same Greek word as in [link]2:12[/link]. The salvation here is the working out of the salvation in [link]2:12[/link]; it means to be sustained and strengthened to live and magnify Christ (see note [link]12[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]). This requires the bountiful supply of the Spirit of Jesus Christ.
This is the supply of the Body of Christ, the church. Imprisonment did not isolate Paul from the Body of Christ or cut him off from the supply of the Body.

The Greek word refers to the supplying of all the needs of the chorus by the choragus, the leader of the chorus. The bountiful supply of the all-inclusive Spirit enabled Paul to live and magnify Christ in his sufferings for Him.

The revelation in the Bible concerning God, Christ, and the Spirit is progressive. The Spirit is mentioned first as the Spirit of God, in relation to creation ([link]Gen. 1:2[/link]). Then, He is mentioned as the Spirit of Jehovah, in the context of God's relationship with man ([link]Judg. 3:10[/link]; [link]1 Sam. 10:6[/link]); as the Holy Spirit, in relation to the conception and birth of Christ ([link]Luke 1:35[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:20[/link]); as the Spirit of Jesus, in relation to the Lord's human living ([link]Acts 16:7[/link]); as the Spirit of Christ, in relation to the Lord's resurrection ([link]Rom. 8:9[/link]); and here as the Spirit of Jesus Christ.[br][br]The Spirit of Jesus Christ is "the Spirit" mentioned in [link]John 7:39[/link]. This is not merely the Spirit of God before the Lord's incarnation but the Spirit of God, the Holy Spirit with divinity, after the Lord's resurrection, compounded with the Lord's incarnation (humanity), human living under the cross, crucifixion, and resurrection. The holy anointing ointment in [link]Exo. 30:23-25[/link], a compound of olive oil and four kinds of spices, is a full type of this compound Spirit of God, who is now the Spirit of Jesus Christ. Here it is not the Spirit of Jesus ([link]Acts 16:7[/link]) or the Spirit of Christ ([link]Rom. 8:9[/link]) but the Spirit of Jesus Christ. The Spirit of Jesus is related mainly to the Lord's humanity and human living; the Spirit of Christ is related mainly to the Lord's resurrection. To experience the Lord's humanity, as illustrated in [link]2:5-8[/link], we need the Spirit of Jesus. To experience the power of the Lord's resurrection, as mentioned in [link]3:10[/link], we need the Spirit of Christ. In his suffering the apostle experienced both the Lord's suffering in His humanity and the Lord's resurrection. Hence, the Spirit to him was the Spirit of Jesus Christ, the compound, all-inclusive, life-giving Spirit of the Triune God. Such a Spirit has, and even is, the bountiful supply for a person like the apostle, who was experiencing and enjoying Christ in His human living and resurrection. Eventually, this compound Spirit of Jesus Christ becomes the seven Spirits of God, who are the seven lamps of fire before God's throne to carry out His administration on earth for the accomplishing of His economy concerning the church, and who are the seven eyes of the Lamb for the transfusing of all that He is into the church ([link]Rev. 1:4[/link]; [link]4:5[/link]; [link]5:6[/link]).

verse.text: According to my earnest expectation and hope that in nothing I will be put to [xref]a[/xref]shame, but with all boldness, as always, even now Christ will be [note]1[/note]magnified [xref]b[/xref]in my body, whether through life or through [xref]c[/xref]death.
verse.note: In the apostle's suffering in his body, Christ was magnified, i.e., shown or declared to be great (without limitation), exalted, and extolled. The apostle's sufferings afforded him opportunity to express Christ in His unlimited greatness. The apostle would have only Christ magnified in him, not the law or circumcision. This book is concerned with the experience of Christ. To magnify Christ under any circumstances is to experience Him with the topmost enjoyment.

verse.text: For to me, to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]live is Christ and to die is [note]2[/note]gain.
verse.note: Paul's life was to live Christ. To him to live was Christ, not the law or circumcision. He would not live the law but would live Christ, not be found in the law but be found in Christ ([link]3:9[/link]). Christ was not only his life but also his living. He lived Christ because Christ lived in him ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]). He was one with Christ in both life and living. He and Christ had one life and one living. They lived together as one person. Christ lived within Paul as Paul's life, and Paul lived Christ without as Christ's living. The normal experience of Christ is to live Him, and to live Him is to magnify Him always, regardless of the circumstances.

[i]Gain[/i] here refers to being with Christ in a higher degree. But in fulfilling God's eternal purpose, being with Christ cannot compare with living Christ for His Body's sake. Hence, Paul chose to live Christ.

verse.text: But if I am to live in the flesh, if this to me is [xref]a[/xref]fruit for [i]my[/i] work, then I do not know what I will choose.
But I am constrained between the two, having the desire to [xref]a[/xref]depart and be [note]1[/note]with Christ, for [i]this is[/i] far better;
verse.note: To be with Christ is a matter of degree, not place. Paul desired to be with Christ in a higher degree, although he was already with Him constantly. Through his physical death he would be with Christ to a fuller extent than he enjoyed in this earthly life.

verse.text: But to remain in the flesh is more necessary for [note]1[/note]your sake.
verse.note: The apostle's consideration was not selfish but was for the saints' sake. He was absolutely occupied by the Lord and the church.

verse.text: And being confident of this, I know that I will remain and continue with you all for your [note]1[/note]progress and [xref]a[/xref]joy of [note]2[/note]the [xref]b[/xref]faith,
verse.note: [i]Progress[/i] refers to the growth in life, and [i]joy,[/i] to the enjoyment of Christ.
[i]The faith[/i] here refers to what the saints believe in ([link]Jude 3[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:7[/link]).

verse.text: That your [note]1[/note]boast may abound in Christ Jesus in me through my coming again to you.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]boasting, glorying,[/i] and [i]rejoicing.[/i]

verse.text: Only, conduct yourselves in a manner [xref]a[/xref]worthy of the [xref]b[/xref]gospel of Christ, that whether coming and seeing you or being absent, I may hear of the things concerning you, that you [xref]c[/xref]stand firm in one spirit, with [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]one soul [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]striving together [i]along[/i] with [note]3[/note]the faith of the gospel,
verse.note: We need not only to stand firm in one spirit in order to experience Christ but also to strive together with one soul along with the faith of the gospel. To be of one soul for the gospel work is more difficult than to be in one spirit for the experience of Christ (see [link]2:20[/link]). To be of one soul requires that, after having been regenerated in our spirit, we go further and be transformed in our soul, especially in our mind, which is the main and leading part of our soul.
Like athletes.
The faith here is personified. The believers should strive together with one soul along with the personified faith (cf. note [link]8[sup]3[/sup] in 2 Tim. 1[/link]).

verse.text: And in nothing being frightened by the opposers, which is to them a [xref]a[/xref]proof of [i]their[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]destruction, but of your [note]2[/note]salvation, and that from God;
verse.note: Destruction of all that they are and do.
Salvation of all that you are and do. See notes [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]12[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: Because to you it has been graciously granted on behalf of Christ not only to believe [note]1[/note]into Him but also to [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]suffer on His behalf,
verse.note: This implies that the believer has an organic union with Christ through believing into Him. To believe into Christ is to have our being merged into His that we two may be one organically.

To suffer on behalf of Christ, after receiving Him and being made one with Him through believing, is to participate in, to have the fellowship of, His sufferings ([link]3:10[/link]) that we may experience and enjoy Him in His sufferings. This is to live Him and magnify Him in a situation in which He is rejected and opposed.

verse.text: Having the same [xref]a[/xref]struggle which you saw in [note]1[/note]me and now hear [i]to be[/i] in me.
verse.note: Paul was a pattern set up by God's grace for His New Testament economy ([link]1 Tim. 1:14-16[/link]). The New Testament believers should experience and enjoy Christ by living and magnifying Him as Paul did in his sufferings for Christ, that they may be fellow partakers with Paul of grace.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]If there is therefore any encouragement in Christ, if any [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]consolation of love, if any [xref]b[/xref]fellowship of spirit, if any [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]tenderheartedness and [xref]d[/xref]compassions,
verse.note: In [link]ch. 1[/link] Paul, being rich in the experience of Christ, presented to the believers an account of his experience. Now in this chapter he asked the believers to have fellowship with him. Such a mutual fellowship of the believers and the apostle is needed for the experience of Christ.
Or, exhortation, encouragement.
I.e., inward affection. Lit., bowels. The same word as in [link]1:8[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Make my [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]joy full, that you [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]think the same thing, having the [note]4[/note]same love, [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]joined in soul, [note]3[/note]thinking [note]6[/note]the one thing,
verse.note: In [link]vv. 1-2[/link] the apostle appealed to the Philippians for their encouragement and consolation. He begged them to make his joy full if they had any encouragement in Christ, any consolation of love, any fellowship of spirit, any tenderheartedness and compassions toward him.

Since this book is concerned with the experience and enjoyment of Christ, which issue in joy, it is a book filled with joy and rejoicing ([link]1:4[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]25[/link]; [link]2:17-18[/link], [link]28-29[/link]; [link]3:1[/link]; [link]4:1[/link], [link]4[/link]).

Among the Philippians there was dissension in their thinking ([link]4:2[/link]), which troubled the apostle. Hence, he asked them to think the same thing, even the same one thing, that they might make his joy full.

This indicates that because of the dissension in their thinking, the Philippian believers had different levels of love. They did not have the same love toward all the saints for the keeping of oneness.

This indicates that the dissension among the Philippians was due to their not being joined in soul, to their not thinking the one thing in their mind, the leading part of their soul. The Philippians' problem was not with their spirit but with their soul, that is, with their mind. They had Christ in their spirit through regeneration, but they did not have Christ in their soul through transformation. Only by having Christ saturate and occupy their entire soul could they be made one in soul.

According to the context of this book, [i]the one thing[/i] here must refer to the subjective knowledge and experience of Christ ([link]1:20-21[/link]; [link]2:5[/link]; [link]3:7-9[/link]; [link]4:13[/link]). Christ, and Christ alone, should be the centrality and universality of our entire being. Our thinking should be focused on the excellency of the knowledge and experience of Christ. Focusing on anything else causes us to think differently, thus creating dissensions among us.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][i]Doing[/i] nothing by way of [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]selfish ambition nor by way of [xref]b[/xref]vainglory, but in [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]lowliness of [note]4[/note]mind considering one another more excellent than yourselves;
verse.note: This may indicate that the dissenting Philippians were doing things out of selfish ambition or vainglory, both of which cause dissensions among believers.
See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
Lowliness is in contrast to both selfish ambition and vainglory. This must be not our natural lowliness but the lowliness of Christ, as illustrated in [link]vv. 7-8[/link].
This indicates again that the problem of dissension among the Philippians was a matter of their untransformed mind. They needed to have the mind that was in Christ (see [link]v. 5[/link]).

verse.text: Not regarding each his own [note]1[/note]virtues, but each the [note]1[/note]virtues of others also.
verse.note: Lit., things; referring to virtues and qualities. We should regard not only our own virtues and qualities but also those of others.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Let [xref]a[/xref]this mind be in you, which was also in [note]2[/note]Christ Jesus,
verse.note: Lit., think this in you. [i]This[/i] refers to the considering in [link]v. 3[/link] and the regarding in [link]v. 4[/link]. This kind of thinking, this kind of mind, was also in Christ when He emptied Himself, taking the form of a slave, and humbled Himself, being found in fashion as a man ([link]vv. 7-8[/link]). To have such a mind requires us to be one with Christ in His inward parts ([link]1:8[/link]). To experience Christ, we need to be one with Him to this extent, that is, in His tender inward feeling and in His thinking.

In [link]ch. 1[/link] the central point is to magnify Christ, to live Christ ([link]vv. 20-21[/link]). In [link]ch. 2[/link] it is to take Christ as our pattern, our model. This pattern is the standard of our salvation ([link]v. 12[/link]). In [link]vv. 5-16[/link] there are four basic elements: Christ ([link]v. 5[/link]), salvation ([link]v. 12[/link]), God ([link]v. 13[/link]), and the word of life ([link]v. 16[/link]). The word of life works out the pattern by the operating God to apply salvation to our daily living. In this way we enjoy Christ and live Him, taking Him as our pattern.

verse.text: Who, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]existing in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]form of God, did [note]3[/note]not consider being [xref]c[/xref]equal with God a treasure to be grasped,
verse.note: The Greek word denotes existing from the beginning, implying the Lord's eternal preexistence.
The expression, not the fashion, of God's being ([link]Heb. 1:3[/link]), identified with the essence and nature of God's person and, hence, expressing them. This refers to Christ's deity.

Although the Lord was equal with God, He did not consider being equal with God a treasure to be grasped and retained; rather, He laid aside the form of God (not the nature of God) and emptied Himself, taking the form of a slave.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]emptied Himself, taking the [note]2[/note]form of a [xref]b[/xref]slave, [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]becoming in the [note]4[/note]likeness of men;
verse.note: I.e., laid aside what He possessed — the form of God.

The same word as that in [link]v. 6[/link]. In His incarnation the Lord did not alter His divine nature; He changed only His outward expression, from the form of God, the highest form, to that of a slave, the lowest form. This was not a change of essence but of state.
I.e., entering into a new state.

The form of God implies the inward reality of Christ's deity; the likeness of men denotes the outward appearance of His humanity. He appeared to men as a man outwardly, but as God He had the reality of deity inwardly.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]being found in [note]2[/note]fashion as a man, He [note]3[/note]humbled Himself, becoming [xref]a[/xref]obedient even unto death, and [i]that[/i] the [note]4[/note]death of a [xref]b[/xref]cross.
verse.note: When Christ became in the likeness of men, entering into the condition of humanity, He was found in fashion as a man.

I.e., the outward guise, the semblance. This is a repetition, in a more particular sense, of the thought of [i]likeness[/i] in [link]v. 7[/link]. What Christ looked like in His humanity was found by men to be in fashion as a man.
Humbling Himself was a further step in emptying Himself. Christ's self-humbling manifested His self-emptying.

The death of a cross is the climax of Christ's humiliation. To the Jews it was a curse ([link]Deut. 21:22-23[/link]). To the Gentiles it was a death sentence imposed on malefactors and slaves ([link]Matt. 27:16-17[/link], [link]20-23[/link]). Hence, it was a shameful thing ([link]Heb. 12:2[/link]).[br][br]The Lord's humiliation involved seven steps: (1) emptying Himself; (2) taking the form of a slave; (3) becoming in the likeness of men; (4) humbling Himself; (5) becoming obedient; (6) being obedient even unto death; and (7) being obedient unto the death of the cross.

verse.text: Therefore also God highly [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]exalted Him and [note]2[/note]bestowed on Him the [note]3[/note]name which is [xref]b[/xref]above every name,
verse.note: The Lord humbled Himself to the uttermost, but God exalted Him to the highest peak.
Lit., graciously bestowed; i.e., freely bestowed.
I.e., the name of Jesus, mentioned in the following verse. See [link]Acts 9:5[/link]. Since the Lord's ascension, there has not been a name on this earth above the name of Jesus.

verse.text: That [note]1[/note]in the name of Jesus [xref]a[/xref]every knee should [note]2[/note]bow, of those who are [note]3[/note]in [xref]b[/xref]heaven and [note]4[/note]on earth and [note]5[/note]under the earth,
verse.note: The name is the expression of the sum total of what the Lord Jesus is in His person and work. [i]In the name of Jesus[/i] means in the sphere and element of all that the Lord is. It is in this way that we worship the Lord and pray to Him.
Lit., bend.
Those who are in heaven are angels.
Those who are on earth are men.
Those who are under the earth are the dead.

verse.text: And every tongue should [note]1[/note]openly confess that Jesus Christ is [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Lord [note]3[/note]to the [xref]b[/xref]glory of God the Father.
verse.note: This is to call on the Lord or on the name of the Lord ([link]Rom. 10:9-10[/link], [link]12-13[/link]).
God made the Lord Jesus, as a man, the Lord in His ascension ([link]Acts 2:36[/link]). Thus, every tongue should confess that He is Lord.

I.e., resulting in. The result of our confessing that Jesus is Lord is that God the Father is glorified. This is the great end of all that Christ is and has done in His person and work ([link]1 Cor. 15:24-28[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]So then, my beloved, even as you have always [note]2[/note]obeyed, not as in my presence only but now much rather in my absence, [note]3[/note]work out your own [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]salvation with [note]5[/note][xref]b[/xref]fear and trembling;
verse.note: I.e., as a consequence of taking Christ as a pattern of obedience in the preceding verses.
This answers to [i]becoming obedient[/i] in [link]v. 8[/link].

I.e., carry out, bring to the ultimate conclusion. We have received God's salvation, which has as its climax our being exalted by God in glory as the Lord Jesus was ([link]v. 9[/link]). We need to carry out this salvation, to bring it to its ultimate conclusion, by our constant and absolute obedience with fear and trembling. We have received this salvation by faith; now we must carry it out by obedience, which includes our being genuinely one in our soul ([link]v. 2[/link]). To receive this salvation by faith is once for all; to carry it out is lifelong.

Not eternal salvation from God's condemnation and from the lake of fire but the daily salvation that is a living Person. This daily salvation results from taking the very Christ whom we live, experience, and enjoy as our inward as well as outward pattern. The main elements of this salvation are Christ as the crucified life ([link]vv. 5-8[/link]) and Christ in His exaltation ([link]vv. 9-11[/link]). When this pattern becomes the believers' inward life, the pattern becomes their salvation. Only this would make the apostle's joy full.[br][br]In [link]ch. 1[/link] salvation comes through the bountiful supply of the Spirit of Jesus Christ, but here salvation comes from the operating God within us. The operating God is actually the Spirit of Jesus Christ. In both these cases salvation is a practical, daily, moment-by-moment salvation. The constant salvation in [link]1:19[/link] is one in which a particular believer is saved from a specific encounter in a particular situation; whereas the constant salvation in [link]2:12[/link] is one in which any believer is saved from ordinary things in common situations in his daily living.
Fear is the inward motive; trembling is the outward attitude.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For it is [note]2[/note]God who [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]operates in you both the [note]4[/note]willing and the [note]5[/note]working for [i]His[/i] [note]6[/note][xref]b[/xref]good pleasure.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] introduces the reason we need to obey always. The reason is that God operates in us. In God's economy we have the Lord Jesus as our pattern ([link]vv. 6-11[/link]), as the standard of our salvation ([link]v. 12[/link]), and we also have God operating in us both the willing and the working that our salvation may be carried out, brought to its ultimate conclusion. It is not that we by ourselves carry it out, but that God operates in us to do it. The only thing we need to do is to obey the inner operating God.

The God who operates in us is the Triune God — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit — the very God who is Christ in us ([link]2 Cor. 13:3a[/link], [link]5[/link]) and the Spirit in us ([link]Rom. 8:11[/link]). The three — the Spirit, God, and Christ — are one.
Or, energizes.

The willing is within; the working is without. The willing takes place in our will, indicating that God's operation begins from our spirit (cf. [link]4:23[/link]) and spreads into our mind, emotion, and will. This corresponds with [link]Rom. 8[/link], where we see that God works from our spirit ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link]), through our mind ([link]Rom. 8:6[/link]), and eventually into our physical body ([link]Rom. 8:11[/link]).
Or, acting. The same Greek word as for [i]operates[/i] in this verse.
I.e., the good pleasure of His will ([link]Eph. 1:5[/link]). God's good pleasure is that we may reach the climax of His supreme salvation.

verse.text: Do all things without [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]murmurings and [xref]b[/xref]reasonings
verse.note: Murmurings are of our emotion and come mainly from the sisters; reasonings are of our mind and come mainly from the brothers. Both frustrate us from carrying out our salvation to the fullest extent and from experiencing and enjoying Christ to the uttermost. The context here indicates that murmurings and reasonings are due to disobedience to God. Obedience to God slays all murmurings and reasonings.

verse.text: That you may be [xref]a[/xref]blameless and [note]1[/note]guileless, [note]2[/note]children of God [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]without blemish in the midst of a [xref]c[/xref]crooked and [note]4[/note]perverted generation, among whom you shine as [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]luminaries in the [note]6[/note]world,
verse.note: Or, simple, artless (not political), innocent ([link]Matt. 10:16[/link]). The Greek root means [i]unmixed. Blameless[/i] describes our outward behavior, and [i]guileless[/i] our inward character.
As children of God, we have God's life and the divine nature ([link]2 Pet. 1:4[/link]).
To be without blemish is the total quality of being blameless and guileless.
Lit., warped, twisted.

The Greek word refers to luminaries that reflect the light of the sun. As such luminaries, the believers shine in the world. They do not possess any light in themselves but have a heavenly ability to reflect the light of Christ. Christ is the sun, with the church as the moon and the believers as the planets to reflect Him by holding forth the word of life ([link]v. 16[/link]).
The dark, corrupt world, which is usurped by Satan ([link]1 John 5:19[/link]; [link]2:15-17[/link]). [i]In the world[/i] can be rendered [i]in the universe.[/i]

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Holding forth the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]word of life, so that I may have a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]boast in the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]day of Christ that I did not [xref]d[/xref]run in vain nor [xref]e[/xref]labor in vain.
verse.note: Lit., applying, presenting, offering. To hold forth the word of life is to apply it, to present it, and to offer it to the world by living out Christ.

Different from the doctrine of dead letters. The word of life is the living breath of God ([link]2 Tim. 3:16[/link]), the Spirit who gives life ([link]John 6:63[/link]). We have the Lord Jesus as our pattern ([link]vv. 6-11[/link]), we have God operating in us ([link]v. 13[/link]), we are God's children, having God's life and the divine nature ([link]v. 15[/link]), we are luminaries qualified to reflect the divine light of Christ ([link]v. 15[/link]), and we have the word of life to hold forth, to present, to others. What a divine and rich provision! By such we are well able to carry out God's salvation to its climax.

The way to make the apostle's joy full ([link]v. 2[/link]) is to live a life that takes Christ as the pattern and carries out God's salvation fully, that the apostle may be able to boast, glory, and rejoice in the believers in the day of Christ.

The day of the Lord's second coming, which is called "the day of the Lord" ([link]1 Thes. 5:2[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:2[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:8[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 1:14[/link]) and "that day" ([link]2 Tim. 1:18[/link]; [link]4:8[/link]). In that day all believers will appear before the judgment seat of Christ to receive the reward each deserves ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]Matt. 25:19-30[/link]).

verse.text: But even if I am being [xref]a[/xref]poured out as a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]drink offering upon the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]sacrifice and [note]3[/note]service of your [note]4[/note]faith, I [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]rejoice, and I [note]6[/note]rejoice together with you all.
verse.note: The drink offering was in addition to the basic offerings revealed in [link]Lev. 1-6[/link] ([link]Num. 15:1-10[/link]; [link]28:7-10[/link]). The basic offerings are types of various aspects of Christ. The drink offering is a type of Christ as enjoyed by the offerer. Christ as the heavenly wine fills the offerer and even causes him to become wine to God. The apostle Paul became such a drink offering ([link]2 Tim. 4:6[/link]) by enjoying Christ in this way, so that he could be poured out as a sacrifice to God upon the believers' faith through the shedding of his blood.
[i]The sacrifice and service of your faith[/i] means that the faith of the Philippian believers was a sacrifice offered to God and also became their service to God.
Like the priestly service. Cf. note [link]25[sup]3[/sup][/link].

Faith here is all-inclusive and includes much more than the act of believing. It is the constitution and total expression of all that the believers have received, experienced, and enjoyed of Christ, including Christ as the basic offerings. Paul's ministry resulted in the all-inclusive faith of the believers. Such a faith was offered as a sacrifice to God by the believers, and Paul rejoiced even to be poured out as a drink offering upon such a sacrifice.
This means that the apostle rejoiced to have his blood shed as a drink offering upon the sacrifice of the believers' faith.
To rejoice together with means to share joy with. The apostle shared his joy with the Philippians in his being martyred for their faith. Hence, the phrase implies that he was congratulating them.

verse.text: And in like manner you also rejoice, and you [note]1[/note]rejoice together with me.
verse.note: The apostle expected that the Philippians would share their joy with him by congratulating him in his being martyred for their faith's sake.

verse.text: But I hope in the Lord Jesus to send [xref]a[/xref]Timothy to you shortly, that I also may be [note]1[/note]encouraged by knowing the things concerning you.
verse.note: Or, of good comfort, of good cheer, refreshed.

verse.text: For I have no one [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]like-souled who will genuinely care for what concerns you;
verse.note: This book deals very much with the believers' soul. We must strive together with one soul along with the personified faith of the gospel ([link]1:27[/link]); we must be joined in soul, thinking the one thing ([link]v. 2[/link]); and we must be like-souled, genuinely caring for the things of Christ Jesus ([link]vv. 20-21[/link]). In the gospel work, in the fellowship among the believers, and in the pursuing of the Lord's interests, our soul is always a problem. Hence, it must be transformed, especially in its leading part, the mind ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]), that we may be of one soul, joined in soul, and like-souled in the Body life.

verse.text: For all [xref]a[/xref]seek their own things, not the things of [note]1[/note]Christ Jesus.
verse.note: According to the context of this book, the things of Christ Jesus are the things concerning the church with all the saints.

verse.text: But you know his [note]1[/note]approvedness, that as a [xref]a[/xref]child with a father he has [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]served with me unto the [xref]c[/xref]gospel.
verse.note: I.e., approved worth, proof of having been tested.
Lit., served as a slave.

verse.text: Him therefore I hope to send immediately, as soon as I see how things go with me.
But I trust in the Lord that I myself also will [xref]a[/xref]come shortly.

But I considered it necessary to send to you [xref]a[/xref]Epaphroditus, my [note]1[/note]brother and [xref]b[/xref]fellow worker and [xref]c[/xref]fellow soldier, and your [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]apostle and [note]3[/note]minister to my [xref]e[/xref]need,
verse.note: First a brother, then a fellow worker, and then a fellow soldier.
One sent with a commission.

Derived from the same Greek word as that for [i]service[/i] in [link]v. 17[/link] and referring to a minister whose ministry is like that of a priest. All New Testament believers are priests to God ([link]1 Pet. 2:9[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:6[/link]). Hence, our ministry to the Lord, in whatever aspect, is a priestly service ([link]vv. 17[/link], [link]30[/link]).

verse.text: Since he [xref]a[/xref]longed after you all and was greatly distressed because you heard that he had become sick;
For indeed he had become [xref]a[/xref]sick, near to death, but God had mercy on him, and not on him only but also on me that I might not have sorrow upon sorrow.
I have sent him therefore the more eagerly, so that when you see him again, you may [xref]a[/xref]rejoice and I may be less sorrowful.
[xref]a[/xref]Receive him therefore in the Lord with all [xref]b[/xref]joy, and [xref]c[/xref]hold such in honor,
Because for the work of Christ he drew near unto death, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]risking his [note]2[/note]life, that he might [xref]b[/xref]fill up your lack of [note]3[/note]service toward me.
verse.note: Venturing, recklessly exposing his life, like a gambler throwing down a stake.
Lit., soul. Epaphroditus was willing to risk his life for the churches and the saints.
See note [link]17[sup]3[/sup][/link]; cf. note [link]25[sup]3[/sup][/link] in this chapter and note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: Finally, my brothers, [xref]a[/xref]rejoice in the Lord. To write the same things to you, for me it is not [note]1[/note]irksome, but for you it is [note]2[/note]safe.
verse.note: Or, wearisome, tedious, troublesome.
To rejoice in the Lord is a safeguard, a security.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Beware of the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]dogs, beware of the [note]2[/note]evil [xref]b[/xref]workers, beware of the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]concision.
verse.note: I.e., ever keep a watchful eye on. On the one hand, the apostle advised the Philippians to rejoice in the Lord; on the other hand, he warned them to ever keep a watchful eye on the Judaizers.

Since no conjunction is used between any of these three clauses, they must refer to the same class of people. Dogs are unclean ([link]Lev. 11:27[/link]), the evil workers are evil, and the concision are those deserving of contempt. ([i]Concision,[/i] meaning [i]mutilation,[/i] is a contemptuous term for [i]circumcision.[/i] See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in Gal. 5[/link].) The dogs here are the Judaizers. In nature the Judaizers are unclean dogs, in behavior they are evil workers, and in religion they are the concision, people of shame. In such a book concerning the experience and enjoyment of Christ, the apostle warned the Gentile believers to be wary of such unclean, evil, and contemptible people.

verse.text: For we are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcision, the ones who [note]2[/note]serve by the Spirit of God and [xref]b[/xref]boast in Christ Jesus and [note]3[/note]have no confidence in the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]flesh,
verse.note: New Testament believers, genuinely circumcised by Christ's crucifixion (see note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in Gal. 5[/link] and note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in Col. 2[/link]). They are absolutely different from the Judaizers. They serve as priests by the Spirit of God, not by the ordinances of law; they boast in Christ, not in the law; and they do not have confidence in the flesh but in the Spirit.
The Greek word for [i]serve[/i] here and the word for [i]service[/i] in [link]2:17[/link] refer to the priestly service.

In [link]vv. 2[/link] and [link]3[/link] there is a threefold contrast: believers who serve by the Spirit of God, in contrast to the dogs; believers who boast in Christ, in contrast to evil workers; and believers who have no confidence in the flesh, in contrast to the concision.

The flesh here comprises all that we are and have in our natural being. The fact that the Judaizers had confidence in their circumcision was a sign that their confidence was in their flesh, not in the Spirit.

verse.text: Though I myself have [i]something[/i] to be confident of in the [xref]a[/xref]flesh as well. If any other man thinks that he has confidence in the flesh, I more:

Circumcised the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]eighth day; of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]race of Israel, of the [note]3[/note]tribe of Benjamin, a [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]Hebrew [i]born[/i] of Hebrews; as to the [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]law, a [note]6[/note][xref]e[/xref]Pharisee;
verse.note: The day for a genuine Israelite to be circumcised ([link]Gen. 17:12[/link]). Being circumcised on that day distinguished him from the Ishmaelites (Ishmael was circumcised thirteen years after his birth — [link]Gen. 17:25[/link]) and proselytes, who were circumcised on a later day.
God's called race, the genuine seed of Abraham ([link]Rom. 11:1[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 11:22[/link]). Paul was not a descendant of the proselytes, who were grafted into the race of God's covenant.
A lovely and faithful tribe, among whom was the royal city of Jerusalem with the temple of God ([link]Deut. 33:12[/link]).
A Hebrew born of Hebrew parents with Hebrew ancestry on both sides.
The law of Moses, which is respected by all orthodox Jews.

The Pharisees were the strictest sect of the Jewish religion ([link]Acts 26:5[/link]; [link]23:6[/link]), a sect exceedingly zealous for the law of Moses. See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].

verse.text: As to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]zeal, [xref]b[/xref]persecuting the church; as to the [xref]c[/xref]righteousness which is in the law, become [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]blameless.
verse.note: Zeal for the law of Moses and for the Jewish religion ([link]Gal. 1:14[/link] and note 1).
I.e., found or proven blameless. This was in the eyes of man, according to man's judgment. In the eyes of God, according to His righteous law, no flesh is blameless ([link]Gal. 2:16b[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But what [note]2[/note]things were gains to me, these I have counted as [note]3[/note]loss [note]4[/note]on account of Christ.
verse.note: [link]Verses 7[/link] and [link]8[/link] are the heart of this book. Here we are initiated into the experience of Christ.
The things mentioned in [link]vv. 5-6[/link].
All the different gains were counted as one loss by Paul because they all issued in one thing, that is, the loss of Christ, as indicated by [i]on account of Christ.[/i]
All the things that were once gains to Paul hindered him and held him back from participating in and enjoying Christ. Hence, on account of Christ all the gains were a loss to him.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But moreover I [note]2[/note]also count [xref]a[/xref]all things to be loss on account of the [note]3[/note]excellency of the [xref]b[/xref]knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord, [note]4[/note]on account of whom I have suffered the loss of all things and count [i]them[/i] as [note]5[/note]refuse that I may [note]6[/note][xref]c[/xref]gain Christ
verse.note: [link]Verses 8-11[/link], being one long sentence, are like the ascending steps of a staircase, bringing us higher and higher until we reach the peak in [link]v. 11[/link].
Paul counted as loss on account of Christ not only the things of his former religion listed in [link]vv. 5[/link] and [link]6[/link] but all other things as well.

The excellency of the knowledge of Christ is derived from the excellency of His person. The Jews consider the law of God given through Moses the most excellent thing in human history; hence, they are zealous for the law. Paul participated in that zeal. But when Christ was revealed to him by God ([link]Gal. 1:15-16[/link]), he saw that the excellency, the supereminence, the supreme preciousness, the surpassing worth, of Christ far exceeded the excellency of the law. His knowledge of Christ issued in the excellency of the knowledge of Christ. On account of this, he counted as loss not only the law and the religion founded according to the law, but all things.

The phrase [i]as to,[/i] which may be rendered [i]according to,[/i] is used three times in [link]vv. 5-6[/link], with the law, zeal, and righteousness. The phrase [i]on account of,[/i] which may be rendered [i]because of,[/i] is used three times in [link]vv. 7-8[/link], with Christ (twice) and with the excellency of the knowledge of Christ. Christ stands in contrast to the law, the zeal for it, and the righteousness in it. The excellency of the knowledge of Christ and Christ Himself are in contrast to all things and to the law. On account of Christ and the excellency of the knowledge of Christ, Paul gave up the law, his zeal for it, the righteousness in it, and all other things. This indicates that Christ and the excellency of the knowledge of Christ are far superior to the law and all things.
Referring to dregs, rubbish, filth, that which is thrown to the dogs; hence, dog food, dung. There is no comparison between such things and Christ.

To know Christ is not merely to have the knowledge concerning Him but to gain His very person. Christ is the embodiment of the fullness of the Godhead ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]) and the reality of the shadows of all positive things ([link]Col. 2:16-17[/link]). To gain something requires the paying of a price. To gain Christ is to experience, enjoy, and take possession of all His unsearchable riches ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]) by paying a price.

verse.text: And be [note]1[/note]found in Him, [note]2[/note]not having my own [xref]a[/xref]righteousness which is [note]3[/note]out of the law, but that which is through [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]faith in Christ, the [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]righteousness which is out of God [i]and[/i] [note]6[/note][i]based[/i] on faith,
verse.note: Paul had been altogether in the Jewish religion under the law and had always been found by others in the law. But at his conversion he was transferred from the law and his former religion into Christ and became "a man in Christ" ([link]2 Cor. 12:2[/link]). Now he expected to be found in Christ by all who observed him — the Jews, the angels, and the demons. This indicates that he aspired to have his whole being immersed in and saturated with Christ that all who observed him might find him fully in Christ. Only when we are found in Christ will Christ be expressed and magnified ([link]Phil. 1:20[/link]).

"Not having my own righteousness...but... the righteousness which is out of God" was the condition in which Paul desired to be found in Christ. He wanted to live not in his own righteousness but in the righteousness of God, and to be found in such a transcendent condition, expressing God by living Christ, not by keeping the law.
The righteousness that comes from man's own effort to keep the law, as mentioned in [link]v. 6[/link].

Lit., faith of Christ. See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 3[/link]. The faith with which we believe in Christ issues from our knowing and appreciating Christ. It is Christ Himself, infused into us through our appreciation of Him, who becomes our faith — the faith in Him. Hence, it is the faith of Christ that brings us into an organic union with Him.
The righteousness that is God Himself lived out of us to be our righteousness through our faith in Christ. Such righteousness is the expression of God, who lives in us.

I.e., on the basis or condition of faith. Faith is the basis, the condition, on which we receive and possess the righteousness that is out of God, the highest righteousness, which is Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]).

verse.text: To [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]know Him and the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]power of His resurrection and the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]fellowship of His sufferings, being [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]conformed to His death,
verse.note: Paul lived in a condition of having not his own righteousness but the righteousness that is out of God, in order to know (to experience) Christ and the power of His resurrection and the fellowship of His sufferings. In [link]v. 8[/link] to have the excellency of the knowledge of Christ is by revelation. But to know Him here is by experience — to have the experiential knowledge of Him, to experience Him in the full knowledge of Him. Paul first received the revelation of Christ, then sought the experience of Christ — to know and enjoy Christ in an experiential way.

The power of Christ's resurrection is His resurrection life, which raised Him from the dead ([link]Eph. 1:19-20[/link]). The reality of the power of Christ's resurrection is the Spirit ([link]Rom. 1:4[/link]). To know, to experience, this power requires identification with Christ's death and conformity to it. Death is the base of resurrection. To experience the power of Christ's resurrection, we need to live a crucified life, as He did. Our conformity to His death affords the power of His resurrection a base from which to rise up that His divine life may be expressed in us.

The participation in Christ's sufferings ([link]Matt. 20:22-23[/link]; [link]Col. 1:24[/link]), a necessary condition for the experience of the power of His resurrection ([link]2 Tim. 2:11[/link]) by being conformed to His death. Paul was pursuing to know and experience not only the excellency of Christ Himself but also the life power of His resurrection and the participation in His sufferings. With Christ, the sufferings and death came first, followed by the resurrection; with us, the power of His resurrection comes first, followed by the participation in His sufferings and conformity to His death. We first receive the power of His resurrection; then by this power we are enabled to participate in His sufferings and live a crucified life in conformity to His death. Such sufferings are mainly for producing and building up the Body of Christ ([link]Col. 1:24[/link]).

To take Christ's death as the mold of one's life. Paul lived a crucified life continually, a life under the cross, just as Christ did in His human living. Through such a life the resurrection power of Christ is experienced and expressed. The mold of Christ's death refers to Christ's experience of continually putting to death His human life that He might live by the life of God ([link]John 6:57[/link]). Our life should be conformed to such a mold by our dying to our human life to live the divine life. Being conformed to the death of Christ is the condition for knowing and experiencing Him, the power of His resurrection, and the fellowship of His sufferings.

verse.text: If perhaps I may [note]1[/note]attain to the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]out-[xref]b[/xref]resurrection from the dead.
verse.note: I.e., arrive at. This requires us to triumphantly run the race for the prize ([link]1 Cor. 9:24-26[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:7-8[/link]).

I.e., the outstanding resurrection, the extra-resurrection, which will be a prize to the overcoming saints. All believers who are dead in Christ will participate in the resurrection from the dead at the Lord's coming back ([link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:52[/link]). But the overcoming saints will enjoy an extra, outstanding portion of that resurrection. See note [link]35[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 11[/link].[br][br]To arrive at the out-resurrection indicates that our entire being has been gradually and continually resurrected. God first resurrected our deadened spirit ([link]Eph. 2:5-6[/link]); then from our spirit He proceeds to resurrect our soul ([link]Rom. 8:6[/link]) and our mortal body ([link]Rom. 8:11[/link]), until our entire being — spirit, soul, and body — is fully resurrected out of our old being by and with His life. This is a process in life through which we must pass and a race that we must run until we arrive at the out-resurrection as the prize. Hence, the out-resurrection should be the goal and destination of our Christian life. We can reach this goal only by being conformed to the death of Christ, by living a crucified life. In the death of Christ we are processed in resurrection from the old creation to the new.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Not that I [note]2[/note]have already [xref]a[/xref]obtained or [note]3[/note]am already [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]perfected, but I [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]pursue, if even I may [note]6[/note]lay hold of [note]7[/note]that for which [xref]d[/xref]I also have been [note]8[/note]laid hold of by Christ Jesus.
verse.note: Paul had already obtained the believers' common salvation by the believers' common faith ([link]1 Tim. 1:14-16[/link]), but he had not obtained the extra portion of resurrection. To obtain that portion he had to pursue, to run, and to finish his course triumphantly.
At his conversion.
In his present seeking.
Or, completed, mature (in life).

The same Greek word as for [i]persecute,[/i] meaning also [i]to press toward, to follow after.[/i] In such a way Paul ran the race to obtain the prize and reach maturity. Before he was saved, he persecuted Christ. After he was saved, he pursued Christ to such an extent that he persecuted Christ, but in a positive way.
Gain, grasp, take possession of, seize.
At his conversion Paul was grasped, taken possession of, by Christ in order that he might grasp, take possession of, Christ. Christ gained him that he might gain Christ ([link]v. 8[/link]).
Gained, grasped, taken possession of, seized. So in [link]v. 13[/link].

verse.text: Brothers, I do [note]1[/note]not account of myself to have laid hold; but one thing I do: [note]2[/note]Forgetting the things which are [xref]a[/xref]behind and [note]3[/note]stretching forward to the things which are before,
verse.note: Paul had experienced and gained Christ tremendously, yet he did not account of himself to have experienced Christ in full or gained Him to the uttermost. He still endeavored to pursue toward the goal — the gaining of Christ to the fullest extent.

In order to gain Christ to the fullest extent, Paul not only forsook his experiences in Judaism but also would not linger in his past experiences of Christ. He forgot the past. Not to forget but to linger in our past experiences, however genuine they were, frustrates our further pursuing of Christ.
Christ is unsearchably rich. There is a vast territory of His riches to be possessed. Paul was stretching out to reach the farthest extent of this territory.

verse.text: I [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]pursue toward the [note]2[/note]goal for the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]prize to which God in Christ Jesus has [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]called [i]me[/i] upward.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]5[/sup][/link].
The fullest enjoyment and gaining of Christ.
The uttermost enjoyment of Christ in the millennial kingdom as a reward to the victorious runners of the New Testament race.

To be called upward is for the obtaining of the prize to which God has called us from above, from the heavens. This heavenly calling ([link]Heb. 3:1[/link]) corresponds with the heavenly commonwealth in [link]v. 20[/link]. It is not an earthly calling like that given to the children of Israel in the flesh. This upward calling is to take possession of Christ, whereas the earthly calling to the children of Israel was to take possession of the physical land.

verse.text: Let us therefore, as many as are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]full-grown, have [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]this mind; and if in anything you are [xref]c[/xref]otherwise minded, this also God will [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]reveal to you.
verse.note: I.e., mature, perfect. Maturity is a stage. We may be mature but not mature in full. [i]Full-grown[/i] here is used in a relative sense — relatively mature, neither childish nor fully mature. Hence, further pursuing, further growth, is needed.

In this book the dealing with the Philippian believers is focused on the mind, the leading part of the soul. This book charges them to strive together with one soul along with the personified gospel ([link]1:27[/link]), to think the same thing, to be joined in soul, even to think the one thing ([link]2:2[/link]; [link]4:2[/link]), to let the mind that was in Christ be in them ([link]2:5[/link]), and to have this one mind, a mind focused on the pursuing and gaining of Christ to the uttermost. When our mind is thus occupied, we have the same mind, thinking the same thing, even thinking the one thing — the fullest gaining of Christ — being joined in soul, like-souled ([link]2:20[/link]), and made one soul.

The pursuing of Christ must be our goal. We should not be otherwise minded. God reveals to us that we need such a mind, a mind focused on the pursuing of Christ. He desires to continually adjust our mind, turning it toward Christ as the center.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Nevertheless [note]2[/note]whereunto we have attained, by the [note]3[/note]same [i]rule[/i] let us [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]walk.
verse.note: This word concludes the preceding verses, charging us with only this one thing: to walk by the same rule.
[i]Whereunto we have attained[/i] modifies [i]walk.[/i]
Same line, same path, same steps. Paul's use of this word indicates that by the same path we should walk according to the elementary principle.

Gk. [i]stoicheo,[/i] meaning [i]to walk orderly,[/i] derived from [i]steicho,[/i] which means [i]to range in regular line, to march in military rank, to keep step, to conform to virtue and piety.[/i] The word is also used in [link]Rom. 4:12[/link] and [link]Gal. 5:25[/link]; [link]6:16[/link]. It is different from the word [i]walk[/i] in [link]vv. 17[/link] and [link]18[/link], which means [i]to live, to deport oneself, to be occupied with, to walk about,[/i] as used in [link]Rom. 6:4[/link]; [link]8:4[/link]; [link]13:13[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:3[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:16[/link]; and [link]Eph. 4:1[/link], [link]17[/link]. By this word the apostle charged us to walk and to order our lives — whereunto we have attained, at the state to which we have attained — by the same rule, in the same line, in the same path, in the same footsteps. Whatever state we have attained to in our spiritual life, we all must walk, as the apostle did, by the same rule, in the same path; that is, we must pursue Christ toward the goal that we may gain Christ to the fullest extent as the prize of the upward calling of God. See note [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in Gal. 5[/link].

verse.text: Be [xref]a[/xref]imitators together of me, brothers, and observe those who thus walk even as you have us as a [xref]b[/xref]pattern.
For [note]1[/note]many walk, of whom I have told you often and now tell you even [xref]a[/xref]weeping, [i]that they are[/i] the enemies of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]cross of Christ,
verse.note: Probably those who practiced the Epicurean philosophy, which promoted indulgence in the pleasure of eating and drinking and encouraged self-gratification in other things, all of which are contrary to the cross of Christ. [link]Verse 2[/link] shows that the Judaizers were a damage to the Philippian believers, and this verse, that the Epicureans were another kind of damage to them. The former was of Jewish origin; the latter, of a heathen source.[br][br]Basically, the exhortation in this chapter was prompted by these two groups of people. In speaking of the Judaizers, it edified the Philippians concerning the matter of dealing with the soul ([link]vv. 1-16[/link]), especially with the mind; and in alluding to the Epicureans, it instructed the believers concerning the matter of dealing with the body ([link]vv. 17-21[/link]). To deal with the soul we must count as refuse all religious, philosophical, and cultural things. In dealing with the body, we should take care of our physical need but should not indulge in excessive physical enjoyment.
The cross of Christ terminated the indulgence of the lusts of the physical body ([link]Gal. 5:24[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Whose end is [xref]a[/xref]destruction, whose god is their [xref]b[/xref]stomach, and [i]whose[/i] glory is in their [xref]c[/xref]shame, who [xref]d[/xref]set their minds on [note]2[/note]earthly things.
verse.note: The Epicureans, who worshipped their belly and served their stomach. In promoting the enjoyment of eating and drinking, they were more concerned with physical indulgence and enjoyment than with ethics or morality. Their stomach was their god.
Physical things, material things, matters of eating and drinking. We need things such as food and clothing; however, we should not indulge ourselves in these things.

verse.text: For our [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]commonwealth exists in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]heavens, from which also we eagerly [xref]c[/xref]await a Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ,
verse.note: Or, citizenship. The Greek word denotes [i]commonwealth, associations of life.[/i]
In contrast to [i]earthly[/i] in the preceding verse. Those who practiced the Epicurean philosophy set their mind on earthly things, but our commonwealth is in the heavens.

verse.text: Who will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]transfigure the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]body of our humiliation to be [xref]c[/xref]conformed to the [note]3[/note]body of His [xref]d[/xref]glory, [note]4[/note]according to His operation by which He is able even to [xref]e[/xref]subject all things to Himself.
verse.note: The transfiguration of our body is the ultimate consummation of God's salvation. In His salvation God first regenerated our spirit ([link]John 3:6[/link]), now is transforming our soul ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]), and consummately will transfigure our body, making us the same as Christ in all three parts of our being.
Our natural body, made of worthless dust ([link]Gen. 2:7[/link]) and damaged by sin, weakness, sickness, and death ([link]Rom. 6:6[/link]; [link]7:24[/link]; [link]8:11[/link]).
Christ's resurrected body, saturated with God's glory ([link]Luke 24:26[/link]) and transcendent over corruption and death ([link]Rom. 6:9[/link]).
The transfiguring of our body is accomplished by the Lord's great power, which subjects all things to Himself ([link]Eph. 1:19-22[/link]). This is the almighty power in the universe.

verse.text: So then, my brothers, beloved and [xref]a[/xref]longed for, my [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]joy and [xref]c[/xref]crown, [note]2[/note]in the same way [xref]d[/xref]stand firm in the Lord, beloved.
verse.note: Joy is inward; a crown is manifested outwardly. The believers were the apostle's inward happiness and outward glory.
In the way presented by the apostle in the foregoing chapter.

verse.text: I exhort Euodias, and I exhort Syntyche, to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]think the same thing in the Lord.
verse.note: This indicates that the two sisters were dissenting from each other; they were not of the same mind. Hence, there was the exhortation in this book to strive together with one soul along with the personified gospel ([link]1:27[/link]), to be joined in soul, thinking the one thing ([link]2:2[/link]), and to have the same mind to pursue Christ ([link]3:14-15[/link]).

verse.text: Yes, I ask you also, genuine [note]1[/note]yokefellow, [note]2[/note]assist them, since they [note]3[/note]contended with me in the gospel, as well as with Clement and the rest of my [xref]a[/xref]fellow workers, whose [xref]b[/xref]names are in the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]book of life.
verse.note: Referring to two oxen pulling a plow; used as a metaphor. [i]Yokefellow[/i] refers to being yoked together with another to bear a common burden.
Assist them to think the same thing in the Lord, and thereby to be one.
Labored with, strove together with, wrestled in company with, as a team of athletes.
A heavenly record of the redeemed in Christ.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Rejoice in the Lord always; again I will say, rejoice.
verse.note: Rejoicing affords us the strength for the oneness spoken of in [link]vv. 2[/link] and [link]3[/link]. Furthermore, rejoicing in the Lord is the secret of having the excellent virtues listed in [link]vv. 5-9[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Let your [note]2[/note]forbearance be known to all men. The Lord is [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]near.
verse.note: The apostle's charge in [link]vv. 5-9[/link] should be the outward expression of the inner reality of the experience of Christ spoken of by him in [link]chs. 1-3[/link].

I.e., reasonableness, considerateness, and consideration in dealing with others, not being strict in claiming one's legal rights. It is in contrast to selfish ambition and vainglory ([link]2:3[/link]) and to murmurings and reasonings ([link]2:14[/link]). It is Christ Himself as an excellent virtue lived out of the believers.
Near in space and time. With respect to space, the Lord is near us, ready to help. With regard to time, the Lord is at hand, coming soon.

verse.text: In nothing [note]1[/note]be [xref]a[/xref]anxious, but in everything, by [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]prayer and petition [note]3[/note]with [xref]c[/xref]thanksgiving, let your requests be made known [note]4[/note]to God;
verse.note: I.e., worry. Anxiety, coming from Satan, is the sum total of human life and disturbs the believers' life of living Christ; forbearance, coming from God, is the sum total of a life that lives Christ. The two are opposites.
Prayer is general, having worship and fellowship as its essence; petition is special, being for particular needs.
Not [i]and[/i] but [i]with.[/i] Both our prayer and our petition should be accompanied by our giving thanks to the Lord.

The Greek word is often translated [i]with[/i] ([link]John 1:1[/link]; [link]Mark 9:19[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:8[/link]; [link]1 John 1:2[/link]). It denotes motion toward, in the sense of a living union and communion, implying fellowship. Hence, the sense of [i]to God[/i] here is [i]in the fellowship with God.[/i]

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]peace of God, which [xref]b[/xref]surpasses every [i]man's[/i] understanding, will [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]guard your [note]3[/note]hearts and your thoughts in Christ Jesus.
verse.note: The result of practicing fellowship with God in prayer is that we enjoy the peace of God. The peace of God is actually God as peace ([link]v. 9[/link]) infused into us through our fellowship with Him by prayer, as the counterpoise to troubles and the antidote to anxiety ([link]John 16:33[/link]).
Or, mount guard over. The God of peace patrols before our hearts and thoughts in Christ, keeping us calm and tranquil.
The heart is the source; the thoughts are the issue.

verse.text: Finally, brothers, what things are [note]1[/note]true, what things are [note]2[/note]dignified, what things are [note]3[/note]righteous, what things are [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]pure, what things are [note]5[/note]lovely, what things are [note]6[/note][xref]b[/xref]well spoken of, if there is any [note]7[/note][xref]c[/xref]virtue and if any [note]8[/note]praise, [note]9[/note]take account of these things.
verse.note: Truthful ethically. It does not mean true in matter of fact.
I.e., venerable, worthy of reverence, noble, grave; implying the idea of dignity, which inspires and invites reverence.
Right, not just, before God and man.
I.e., single in intention and action, without any mixture.
I.e., lovable, agreeable, endearing.
I.e., of good repute, attractive, winning, gracious.
Meaning [i]excellence,[/i] that is, ethical energy exhibited in vigorous action. See notes [link book="2 Pet." chapter="1"]3[sup]11[/sup][/link] and [link]5[sup]4[/sup] in 2 Pet. 1[/link].

I.e., things worthy of praise, as the companion of virtue. The first six items are categorized under [i]what things are;[/i] the last two, under [i]if any.[/i] This indicates that the last two items are a summing up of the first six, in all of which are some virtue or excellence and something worthy of praise.
Think about, ponder, consider.

verse.text: The things which you have also learned and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]received and heard and [note]2[/note]seen in me, [note]3[/note]practice these things; and the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]God of peace will be with you.
verse.note: Not only learned but also received.
Not only heard but also seen.
Not only should the believers think about the things mentioned in [link]v. 8[/link]; they should also practice the things they have learned, received, heard, and seen in the apostle.

The God of peace is the source of all the things mentioned in [link]vv. 8[/link] and [link]9[/link]. By our fellowshipping with Him and having Him with us, all these virtues will issue forth in our life.

verse.text: But I [xref]a[/xref]rejoiced in the Lord greatly because now at length you have caused your thinking for me to [note]1[/note]blossom anew; for which matter you had indeed taken thought, but lacked opportunity.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]to sprout and bloom,[/i] implying that the Philippian believers' thinking toward the apostle was a matter of life. For some time their thinking for Paul had been dormant. But when Paul wrote this Epistle, their thinking for him had begun to blossom anew, just like a plant's sprouting and blooming.

verse.text: Not that I speak according to [xref]a[/xref]lack, for I have learned, in whatever circumstances I am, to be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]content.
verse.note: Self-sufficient, satisfied in oneself. This is a word used by the Stoics, who taught that a person should be content in all circumstances. Being content is the opposite of the Epicurean practice referred to in [link]3:18-19[/link].

verse.text: I know also how to be [note]1[/note]abased, and I know how to [note]2[/note]abound; [note]3[/note]in everything and in all things [note]4[/note]I have learned the secret both to be [note]5[/note]filled and to [xref]a[/xref]hunger, both to [note]6[/note]abound and to [note]7[/note][xref]b[/xref]lack.
verse.note: Humbled, in lowly circumstances.
To live in abundance.

[i]In everything[/i] means in each matter; [i]in all things[/i] means in all matters. Together, these two phrases encompass all the things in the course of human life. Paul learned the secret of experiencing Christ — to experience Him in everything and in every place.

Lit., I have been initiated. The metaphor here refers to a person's being initiated into a secret society with instruction in its rudimentary principles. After Paul was converted to Christ, he was initiated into Christ and the Body of Christ. He then learned the secret of how to take Christ as life, how to live Christ, how to magnify Christ, how to gain Christ, and how to have the church life, all of which things are rudimentary principles.
Satisfied.
To have abundance, sufficiency, more than enough.
To be in want, to suffer privation.

verse.text: I am able to do all things [note]1[/note]in Him who [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]empowers me.
verse.note: Paul was a person in Christ ([link]2 Cor. 12:2[/link]), and he desired to be found in Christ by others. Now he declared that he was able to do all things in Him, the very Christ who empowered him. This is an all-inclusive and concluding word on his experience of Christ. It is the converse of the Lord's word in [link]John 15:5[/link] concerning our organic relationship with Him, "Apart from Me you can do nothing."

The Greek word means [i]makes dynamic inwardly.[/i] Christ dwells in us ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]). He empowers us, makes us dynamic from within, not from without. By such inward empowering Paul was able to do all things in Christ.

verse.text: Nevertheless you did well to have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fellowship with me in my [note]2[/note]affliction.
verse.note: This was the fellowship unto the furtherance of the gospel ([link]1:5[/link]), by their supplying of material things to the apostle ([link]v. 18[/link]).
Referring to Paul's imprisonment ([link]1:17[/link]).

verse.text: And you yourselves also know, Philippians, that in the beginning of the [xref]a[/xref]gospel, when I [xref]b[/xref]went out from [xref]c[/xref]Macedonia, no church had [note]1[/note]fellowship with me in the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]account of [note]3[/note]giving and receiving except [note]4[/note]you only;
verse.note: This fellowshipping (sharing) is the fellowship unto the furtherance of the gospel mentioned in [link]1:5[/link] and [link]4:14[/link].
The Philippian believers' supplying of material things to the apostle opened an account with the apostle.
The supplying and receiving of material things to meet the apostle's need in his gospel work.
The church in Philippi was a unique example in the supplying of the sent one's needs for the furtherance of the gospel.

verse.text: For even in [xref]a[/xref]Thessalonica you sent both once and again to my [xref]b[/xref]need.
Not that I seek the [note]1[/note]gift, but I seek the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]fruit which increases to your [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]account.
verse.note: The material things given to the Lord's servant for the Lord's interests.
The result of their fellowship, participation, in the apostle's gospel work. This will be a reward in the day of the Lord.
The account opened in [link]v. 15[/link]. We should follow the Philippians' example by opening such an account and keeping its credit side continually increasing in the fruit of our giving.

verse.text: But I have received in full all things and abound; I have been [note]1[/note]filled, receiving from [xref]a[/xref]Epaphroditus the [note]2[/note]things from you, a [note]3[/note]sweet-smelling savor, an acceptable [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]sacrifice, well pleasing to God.
verse.note: Fully supplied.
The material things given as a supply to the apostle.
The same Greek phrase as in [link]Eph. 5:2[/link]. A sweet-smelling odor of sacrifices offered to God ([link]Gen. 8:21[/link]).

The Philippians' material gift, given to supply the apostle's need, was considered by him a sacrifice to God, acceptable and well pleasing ([link]Heb. 13:16[/link]). Paul indicated in his appreciation that what the Philippians did toward him was done toward God. This implies that he had the assurance that he was one with God and that his work was by God and for God.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]my God will [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]fill [note]3[/note]your every need [note]4[/note]according to His riches, [note]5[/note]in glory, [note]6[/note]in Christ Jesus.
verse.note: The apostle in his experience had the conviction and assurance that he was one with God and that God was his God. Since he considered the Philippians' material gift to him a sacrifice to God, he believed with assurance that God, who was one with him and who was his God, would richly repay the Philippians.
Fully supply, satisfy to the full.
Since the Philippians cared for God's sent one, God would care for their every need.
God supplies us according to His riches, not according to our needs. His riches exceed our needs.

[i]In glory[/i] modifies [i]fill.[/i] Glory is the expression of God; it is God expressed in splendor. God's rich supply to the believers, who are His children, expresses God and bears the glory of God. The apostle assured the Philippians that God would abundantly supply all their needs in a way that would bring them into His glory.

[i]In Christ Jesus[/i] also modifies [i]fill.[/i] Christ, the all-inclusive One, is the base, the element, the sphere, and the channel in and by which God cares for His people according to His riches and in glory. This indicates that even the believers' giving and receiving of material things are intimately related to the experience of Christ.

verse.text: Now to [note]1[/note]our God and Father be the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory forever and ever. [note]3[/note]Amen.
verse.note: God is not only the apostle's God but also the believers'.

Glory is God expressed in His splendor and excellency for our appreciation. For glory to be to God means that God is expressed in this way. Our giving in Christ, which is to God for God's interests, brings in God's glory, not only for our enjoyment but also for God's glorification.
See note [link]13[sup]5[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].

verse.text: Greet every saint in Christ Jesus. The brothers who are with me greet you.
All the [xref]a[/xref]saints greet you, and especially [note]1[/note]those of Caesar's household.
verse.note: Caesar's household comprised all who were attached to the palace of Nero. Some of these were converted through contact with Paul and became believers in Christ in Rome.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]spirit.
verse.note: God in Christ as our supply and enjoyment, conveyed to us and realized through the bountiful supply of the Spirit of Jesus Christ ([link]1:19[/link]). To experience Christ as Paul did, we need this grace.

Our regenerated spirit, which is indwelt by the Spirit of Christ. It is in this spirit of ours that we experience and enjoy Christ as Paul did.[br][br]This book, which is concerned with the experience of Christ, points out to us at the beginning, in [link]ch. 1[/link], that it is the bountiful supply of the Spirit of Jesus Christ that enables us to live Christ, even to magnify Christ under any circumstances, that we may enjoy Him as the uttermost salvation. Here, at the end of the book, we are told that our experience and enjoyment of Christ must take place in our spirit, which has been regenerated to be the dwelling place and vessel of the Triune God. Therefore, this is altogether a matter of the union and mingling of the processed Triune God, who has become the all-inclusive, life-giving Spirit, and the spirit of us, the tripartite men, who are being transformed by such a Spirit. We must live and act in our wonderful spirit by the Triune God as the wonderful Spirit. Only then can we experience and enjoy the Triune God, who was processed through incarnation, crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension, as the inexhaustibly sufficient grace and thus become His fullness, His expression.
